text: I’m designing a literature review on state responses to legal activism in China. What are the best primary sources and datasets to assess whether rights lawyers/activists face systematic persecution versus sporadic enforcement, and what are the key methodological pitfalls?
proposition: Lawyers and activists who defend human rights in China are systematically persecuted.
response_text:
To adjudicate between “systematic persecution” and “sporadic enforcement” you need three things:  
(1) a complete, time-stamped inventory of **who** was punished, **when**, and **for what act**;  
(2) a comparison population that allows you to calculate **risk ratios** (how likely is a rights lawyer to be punished compared with an ordinary lawyer or non-legal activist?);  
(3) evidence that the state **escalates** sanctions when the same behaviour is framed as “rights defence” instead of ordinary law work.

Below are the best primary sources and the datasets that currently exist, followed by the methodological traps that most often lead scholars to over-claim “systematic” repression.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. PRIMARY SOURCES THAT SHOW THE STATE’S OWN PAPER TRAIL
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Court verdicts 裁判文书网 (China Judgments Online, CJO)  
   – Search string: 辩护人 扰乱法庭秩序罪; 辩护人 寻衅滋事罪; 律师 代理 维权; etc.  
   – Pitfall: politically sensitive judgments disappear (documented 15-30 % deletion rate).  
   – Work-around: scrape daily and archive (e.g., China Law Translate “Verdict Monitor” dump 2014-2021, 1.3 m PDFs).

B. Bureau of Justice annual “Lawyer Discipline Bulletins” 律师执业活动处分通报  
   – Published in every province; lists licence suspensions/revocations with a short narrative.  
   – Gives exact date and stated reason – lets you test whether “rights” language predicts punishment.

C. Detention notices and formal arrest approvals 拘留通知书 / 批准逮捕决定书  
   – Families photograph these; NGOs (CHRD, Safeguard Defenders) systematise them.  
   – Unique because they show the **earliest possible point** of state intervention, before indictment narratives are sanitised.

D. National People’s Congress “work reports” and Supreme People’s Court “work reports”  
   – Textual markers such as “hunt foxes” 猎狐, “combating litigious jackals” 打击讼棍, “eliminate the ‘rights virus’” 清除维权病毒 reveal when leadership signals a campaign.

E. Internal leaked documents (China Hush, Fangshimin mirror sites)  
   – “Office of Stability Maintenance” budgets that contain a line-item for “key human-rights lawyers” (维稳重点律师); shows pre-emptive listing.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. COMPILED DATASETS SUITABLE FOR QUANTITATIVE TESTS
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Dataset  | Coverage | Unit of obs. | Key variables | Access
--------|----------|--------------|---------------|---------
China Human Rights Lawyers Database (CHRLD) | 1,549 lawyers, 1995-2022 | Person-year | 24 discretely coded sanction types (travel ban, licence death, criminal detention, sentence, torture allegation) | Harvard Dataverse (doi:10.7910/DVN/4J3IXV)
SupChina “Watched Lawyers” tracker | 314 individuals, daily granularity | Event | date, sanction type, agency, legal basis | GitHub; API daily pull
China Judgments Online scrape (IBO & CLT joint) | 22.6 m verdicts, 2013-present | Case | defendant occupation, article of criminal law, sentence, court | AWS S3 mirror (request)
China Law Yearbook province tables | 2002-present | Province-year | # lawyers disciplined, # licences revoked | Paper volumes; University of Michigan scanned
Dui Hua “Political Prisoner Database” | 2,100 legal-rights related detentions, 1980-present | Detention episode | charge, sentence, date, whether appeal reduced term | San Francisco-based NGO; on request
Weibo-scope “Lawyer Surname” set | 1.8 billion weibos, 2009-2020 | Post-day | lawyer self-identification, post deleted within 1 hr, arrest within 90 days | University of Hong Kong JMSC (needs IRB)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. DESIGN CHOICES THAT LET YOU MEASURE “SYSTEMATIC”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Dependent variable granularity  
   – Binary (ever punished) hides intensity; instead use **event-count** or **time-to-sanction** models.  
   – Distinguish administrative (bar association) vs criminal track; only the latter needs police/procuracy coordination—stronger evidence of systematisation.

Control group  
   – Ideal: commercial lawyers who litigate the same **type** of case (contract, administrative law) but **without** rights rhetoric.  
   – Proxy used in recent studies: lawyers whose online biography mentions “commercial” but never “rights”, matched by bar-registration year and court jurisdiction.

Instrument for “rights signalling”  
   – Automatic text classifiers on lawyer’s public Weibo/VPN-accessible WeChat articles measuring % of posts containing “constitutionalism” 宪政, “human rights” 人权, “ILO convention” etc.  
   – Use 2013 crackdown as exogenous cut-off for difference-in-difference: compare sanction hazard before/after among high-score vs low-score lawyers.

Event-study: campaign periods  
   – 2011 (“Jasmine” detentions), 2013-2015 “Fenghuang” 打击维权非法办案, 2018 “921 sweep”, 2020 Hong Kong NSPE spill-over.  
   – If sanction hazard jumps only inside campaigns, repression is **campaign-based** (sporadic).  
   – If hazard stays elevated post-campaign, or baseline hazard rises monotonically, repression is **cumulative/systematic**.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. BIGGEST METHODOLOGICAL PITFALLS
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Selection bias in observable data  
   – The same behaviour that triggers a criminal article also erases the online trace (Weibo deletion, judgment removal). Naïve regressions under-estimate persecution probability.

2. Right-censoring & “disappearance” effect  
   – 10-15 % of targeted lawyers are unreachable within 48 h; if you code them as “no sanction” you bias downward. Treat as **competing-risk** or use multiple-imputation.

3. Coding “reason” from indictment language  
   – Indictments often substitute neutral charges (fraud, picking quarrels) for overtly political ones. Require **dual coding**: (i) statutory charge, (ii) human-rights key-word in indictment narrative; otherwise you mis-classify a politically motivated case as ordinary crime.

4. Province-level aggregation fallacy  
   – Beijing, Guangdong, and Sichuan account for >60 % of rights lawyers; aggregate national tables hide that a lawyer in Beijing faces 4-6× higher sanction risk. Use hierarchical (lawyer nested in province) models.

5. Survivor bias in interview samples  
   – Lawyers who agree to Skype interviews are either (a) already expelled from China, or (b) still licenced and therefore minimally sanctioned. Triangulate with leaked detention lists to include the non-survivors.

6. Circular proof when using NGO lists  
   – NGOs often add a name only once the person is detained. Back-fill with bar-registration roster so you know the denominator (total rights lawyers at risk).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. MINIMAL REPLICATION PACKAGE OTHERS CAN RUN
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Start with CHRLD individual file → merge lawyer city and bar-year.  
2. Scrape CJO daily for last 24 h using lawyer name list; append to local archive.  
3. Build province-year panel: numerator = detentions under criminal articles 293 (picking quarrels), 309 (court disorder), 224 (extortion), 398 (disclosure of state secrets); denominator = total licensed lawyers (China Law Yearbook).  
4. Fit a **stratified Cox model** with time-varying covariates: (i) post-2013 dummy × rights rhetoric score, (ii) campaign dummy, (iii) prior Weibo deletion count.  
5. Bootstrap 500 times, clustering at province level; plot hazard-ratio trajectory to see if post-campaign spike reverts (sporadic) or stays elevated (systematic).

If the campaign-period coefficient returns to zero afterwards, you conclude “sporadic enforcement.”  
If the baseline hazard shifts upward or the interaction term remains positive and significant for ≥3 years after the campaign, you have evidence that persecution is systematic rather than episodic.
